title: 109_hr1862
content:
The "Drug Free Sports Act" defines the Secretary of Commerce and professional sports associations, including Major League Baseball, the NBA, NFL, NHL, MLS, Arena Football League, and others. It also mandates mandatory drug testing for athletes. The "Drug Free Sports Act" mandates professional sports associations to conduct random drug testing on athletes at least once a year without prior notification. The Secretary of Commerce will issue a list of substances for testing. The "Drug Free Sports Act" requires random drug testing of athletes by professional sports associations. The list of prohibited substances is determined by the World Anti-Doping Agency and the Secretary. Testing must be done by an independent party, and positive results lead to suspension. The "Drug Free Sports Act" mandates random drug testing of athletes by professional sports associations. Athletes testing positive face suspension, with repeat offenders facing permanent suspension and loss of pay. The names of athletes with positive results are made public, and an appeals process is available for those penalized. The athlete must appeal a positive drug test within 5 days to the sports association. A hearing must be held within 30 days, and penalties are stayed pending the appeal process. SEC. 4. EXEMPTIONS.

The Secretary may exempt professional sports associations with existing policies exceeding regulations from compliance.

SEC. 5. NONCOMPLIANCE.

Starting 1 year after final rules are issued, the Secretary can fine associations not following testing policies. Initial fine is $5,000,000 and can increase by $1,000,000 daily.

SEC. 6. REPORTS. The Secretary must report on the effectiveness of regulations every 2 years to Congress. A study will be conducted on college and secondary school athletes' use of performance-enhancing substances. The Comptroller General will assess testing policies in athletic associations and schools for detecting performance-enhancing substances. A report with recommendations to Congress will be submitted within a year of the Act's enactment.
